text:
*[Bug 18666] New: Ctrl-D or DEL requests R to quit in Rterm*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18666>

            Bug ID: 18666
           Summary: Ctrl-D or DEL requests R to quit in Rterm
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.3.x
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Windows GUI / Window specific
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:murdoch.duncan@gmail.com|murdoch.duncan@gmail.com>

This was posted to R-help by Iago Giné Vázquez <iago.gine@sjd.es> about Rterm
on Windows:

This has been confirmed by another user.  The undesired behaviour is requesting
an exit when all the user wanted is to delete some characters, but pushed the
DEL key too many times.

text:
*[Bug 18667] New: Documentation for %/% seems incorrect*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18667>

            Bug ID: 18667
           Summary: Documentation for %/% seems incorrect
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.3.x
          Hardware: x86_64/x64/amd64 (64-bit)
                OS: macOS
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Documentation
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:n.g.davies@gmail.com|n.g.davies@gmail.com>

Documentation for Arithmetic {base} states:

I think the last sentence has it backwards. If 
the representation of 0.2 were slightly higher 
than 0.2, and following basic algebra, I would
think that the answer to 1 %/% 0.2 "should" be
5, but that most platforms would give 4, not
the other way around. Indeed, on my computer,
which certainly uses IEC 60559 (aka IEEE 754)
for type double, 1 %/% 0.2 gives 4, not 5.

elements.text:
Bug ID: 18667
           Summary: Documentation for %/% seems incorrect
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.3.x
          Hardware: x86_64/x64/amd64 (64-bit)
                OS: macOS
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Documentation
          Assignee:

Documentation for Arithmetic {base} states:

I think the last sentence has it backwards. If 
the representation of 0.2 were slightly higher 
than 0.2, and following basic algebra, I would
think that the answer to 1 %/% 0.2 "should" be
5, but that most platforms would give 4, not
the other way around. Indeed, on my computer,
which certainly uses IEC 60559 (aka IEEE 754)
for type double, 1 %/% 0.2 gives 4, not 5.
